VOL. XXV. No. 21
VARSITY CLUB MAKES ANNOUNCEMENTS
$1400 Lost on Basket-Ball Season.
More Working Capital Needed.
Eleven Students Elected to
Membership.—More
•

Wanted.

The Varsity Club announces
that it has lost $1400 on the basket-ball team this season. This
loss will be met by the surplus
from the football receipts; but,
since the Club expects to lose
about $1000 apiece on both baseball and lacrosse this spring, more
working capital will be needed.
The present capital of the Club
is invested in the additional stands
and other equipment, and can not
be used for its current expenses.
It is estimated that about $4000
Will be needed for this purpose until the close of next year's football
season. The Club plans to obtain
this from the sale of additional
stock. .
The Varsity Club intends to present a printed report of its receipts and disbursements some
time before the close of the scholastic year. Such reports are regularly presented at many other
colleges, and when the non-athletic
fee goes into effect next year will
become a necessity at our own
University for non-athletic as well
as 'athletic activities.
Eleven Undergraduates have
been elected to membership in the
Club, and a drive for more student
members is being made. All "H"
men are eligible and should see
either Bill Wood or Cashell concerning their applications.
Evalyne—They say that Egbert
was a bird at going over the top.
George—He was. He quailed
every time he heard a shot.—Chaparral.
•
Robert A. Watson, field
clerk, U. S. A., will be at the
military office on Wednesday
and Thursday, March 16 and
17, to distribute Victory
Medals to students of the
university who are entitled to
them. This number embraces all who served during
the war in all branches, including the S. A. T. C. Discharge papers must be presented.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 15, 1921
HOPKINS BOWS TO CENTRE
IN LAST GAME OF SEASON
After Leading Through First Half J. H.
U. Courtmen Weaken and Kentuckians Win By Three Points.
Mayer and Owings Star.

In one of the best played and
most exciting basketball games of
the season, Johns Hopkins gave
Centre College of Kentucky a hard
fight to maintain its reputation of
having gone through the entire
season with but one defeat. The
Black and Blue squad played a
good game at all times, and at the
end of the first half were leading,
the score being 18 to 17, and from
then on it was quite evident to
the large crowd that if Centre expected to win she must come back
stiong in the second half.
Centre scored first, Mayer shooting a foul; Bobby Owings scored
two for Hopkins and Bill Wood
made a pretty shot from the side,
Keyes followed by making a spectacular one.hand shot; Bo McMillan shot two goals in quick succession from under the basket and
then Walden shot from the center
of the floor and caged another.
Mayer, Centre's individual star,
made seven foul goals during the
first half.
Hopkins came back in the second half determined to win with
the pass work noticeably improved. Still leading, the Black
and Blue five continued to run up
the score, first to 20 and then to
22. Then Centre led the score
with a foul and Bo McMillan spot
a goal which placed Hopkins on
the short end of a 24 to 22 score.
Centre began to play for time as
Hopkins became more aggressive.
Owings made a foul and Mayer
came back with a field goal which
ended the scoring, the final being
26 to 23.

ROWLAND ELECTED PRESIDENT OF SWIMMING
ASSOCIATION
Succeeds J. H. Reilly As Head of Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association—Hopkins Second To Rutgers In 1921 Team Standing.

Davidge Rowland, captain of
the Johns Hopkins swimming
team, was elected president of the
Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association at the annual meeting on
March 5 at Rutgers College, New
Brunswick, N. J. The elections
followed the meet held on that date
to decide the individual championships of the league. Jaegel, of
Lehigh, was c.hosen as secretary,
and E. F. O'Dair, of Rutgers, was
named treasurer.
The league at present includes
Johns Hopkins, Lehigh, Swarthmore and Rutgers, although it is
highly probable that Lafayette and
Stevens will be admitted to membership in the near future. Washington and Lee and Carnegie Tech
may also become associate members of the league.
A new ruling was adopted,
which provides that a contestant
in a dual meet between nfembers
of the league may compete in not
more than three events, and in
either the back stroke or the breast
stroke.
The recent meet held in New
Brunswick was not intended to
decide the team championship,
which is determined• in the dual
meets of the league but was simthe individual
ply staged to pick'
champion in each event. All first
places were won by Rutgers men
except the breast stroke, which
was captured by Rowland, of Hopkins. The final standing in the
team competition is as follows:

PRICE 10 CENTS
TREW STARS IN "ARMS AND
.THE MAN"
Draws Much Applause From Lyric
Audience—Dramatic Club's Production Great Success—Badillo and Smith Responsible for Excellent
Scenery and
Settings.

It was the general consensus of
opinion of those present at the
Lyric last Friday night that the
Dramatic Club's presentation of
"Arms and the Man" was quite the
success that it was expected to be.
Bartus Trew as Captain Bluntschi,
the hero, was distinctly the star of
the cast, his great ease and superb
acting drawing from the audience
several bursts of enthusiastic applause.
The play was filled with many
comic parts, which were noticed
throughout the three acts, in spite
of the fact that the acoustics of
the Lyric made it necessary for
the actors to speak out of their
natural conversational tones. In
all except a few places the lines
could be distinctly heard over the
entire theater, in spite of the unusual size for an amateur play.
Great excitement was shown in
all the "embraces," either because
the actors, naturally unused to
"clinching" in real life, did it awkwardly, or because the audience,
thinking of the players as themselves, realized the unlikelihood of
Brawner and Moran "coming together" elsewhere but upon the
stage. Many laughs were also produced during the first act by the
"nighties" worn by Riana and
Catherine, and by the former's
antics in getting into bed, which
seemed to appeal very strongly to
the many students present.
The presence of the Undergraduate Orchestra, which, under the
leadership of "Mike" Bowers
played between the acts of the performance, served to make the
Club's presentation for •the first
time an "All-Hopkins" affair.
The actors, who have had the
rare opportunity being coached
by Miss Clementine Walter, well

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. ]5, 1921

At the annual election of the
Board of Control of the NEWSLETTER held last week, H. Douglas
Cotton, '22, was re-elected editorin-chief; Norvell E. Miller, '23,
was elected managing editor;
Frederick W. Lipps, '22, business
manager, and Glover C. Fallon,
'23, circulatioh manager. The new
board will hold office from next
week's issue until March, 1922.
LIMITED ENROLLMENT NECESSARY

Must the undergraduate enrollment of Hopkins be limited as has
been the undergraduate enrollment
of so many other colleges? This
is a question which has been before
the undergraduates for some time
and which can be answered, we
believe, only in the affirmative.
The university has been and is
totally unprepared to handle the
almost 100 per cent. increase in
student enrollment which has
taken place in the last few years.
We are not the only educational
institution to be faced by these
conditions, but nearly all of the
other colleges have already
adopted some drastic measures to
curtail the number of entering
students.

• We must frankly face the fact
that, as President Goodnow said,
the facilities of the university
scarcely justify the present large
enrollment and are certainly inadequate for a larger number of
In justice to the
students.
students who are already enrolled
and to those who are going to enter
in the future, the university must
limit 'the number of undergraduates so that it can give each the
proper attention. Restricting the
size of the entering class is the
logical way to bring this situation
about.
If the entering class is to be restricted in numbers there must be
some definite basis of selection, as
the number of applicants will
greatly exceed the number which
can be admitted.
This basis of selection should be,
we feel, not scholarship alone, but
the qualities of leadership and
character of the applicant should
also be taken into account. The
selection would be based, therefore, on scholarship, qualities of
leadership and character.
Such additional information as
would be required could be obtained by the addition to the present application blank of such
questions as the committee of admissions and advanced standing

WISHES LESS FREQUENT EXAMS

The organization meeting of the
tennis team was held last Wednesday at 12.20 P. M.in Room 112.
The candidates, who numbered
about 20, were addressed by Captain Duffy and Manager Pickford.
The main purpose of the meeting was to obtain the names and
past records of those enrolling in
the sport. Announcement was
made that the courts will be put
into condition as soon as possible, •
after which the spring tournaments will be started. A general
entry, blank and a copy of the
tournament rules will be posted in
several days' time.
The schedule as arranged thus
far presents some very attractive
and some rather formidable
matches. It is therefore hoped
that a team of- the calibre of previous Hopkins organizations Will
be produced.

The Editor of The News-Letter:
Dear Sir—I read with interest

Hopkins has tried to get away
from the schoolboy system of pushing the students through their

the greatest sum total of facts and
information but it would never
develop the thirst for knowledge,
and it would never develop any
powers of original thinking. How
Often do you find a boy in prep
school who turns aside from his
daily assignments to make some
independent inquiries? Individualism is stultified by routine.
There are other incidental objections to this system, such as the
number of instructors re'quirea..
In the second place we might
put into effect the system which,
I believe has been the theoretical
one at Hopkins—responsibility on
the part of the student, checked
up by semi-annual examinations.
Such a method has a fatal flaw.
An hour's' work during the week
before exams is worth three hours
earlier in the year, as far as passing is concerned/ I would not
hesitate to say that seven-eights
of the students here are chiefly *concerned with the results of their
examinations and not with the acquisition of knowledge. Hence
they cram and acquire a knowledge which does not last two weeks
after the examination. The work
which counts, work done regularly
through the year, is generally neglected, except in preparation for
quizzes. This sounds like a very
naive attack on a well planned
system, but I am presenting the
students' view, and they are generally agreed in regard to these
facts. What Senior, Phi Beta
Kappa men included, can pass a
course which he has not taken
since Freshman year?
Lastly, a college may adopt the
English system of placing absaute
responsibility on the student, by
Postponing examinations for one,
or, better, two or three years. This
places his work in a new light in
the eyes of the student. He realizes
that the best way to pass is to

learn, and he studies with that end
in view, reading all the important
literature of a subject and reviewing when necessary. We sometimes encounter a subject which
cannot be crammed, for it covers
That is the
too much ground.
secret of this-last alternative.No
man can put off all the work covered in such a long period. He
cannot afford to procrastinate or
be very irregular in his studying.
The responsibility is obvious—the
inevitability slaps him in the face.
Such a system would afford the
student the greatest possible incentive and requirements of the
university could be standardized
and adjusted at will. The English
universities are ahead of us, and
their success shows that high
school methods are not necessary
in college.

DANCE

TO FOLLOW JUNIORSENIOR DEBATE

The Junior Class has decided
to take a step that will, if successful, set a tradition that future
classes will find most beneficial
to follow. The Junior-Senior debate this year is to be followed•
for the first time in the history of
Hopkins debating by an informal
dance. The debate, the subject
of which is the American immigration question, will begin
promptly at 8 o'clock on the night
of March 19, and anyone who is
not in the C. E. Hall by that hour
will not be admitted to the dance
afterward.
The Juniors, in aranging their
debating contest this year and
remembering the woefully small
numbers attendant on former class
debates, decided that some step
must be taken to assure the debaters an audience -large enough
to be called an audience. The
dance plan was the result. It was
thought best to have a card dance,
although it will be an informal one. Decorations will not be
lacking, for those used at the
cotillion the night before will still
be in place. The Undergraduate
Orchestra will furnish the necessary jazz, and dancers needing
refreshment will find it in the
punch for which 1922 has voted
the sum of $15 from its treasury.
The committee for the debate
consists of Cotton, '22 (chairman); Pickford, '21; Wood, '22,
Cards of
and Vanneman, '23.
admission may be obtained from
members of this committee. The
only restriction upon the issuing
of tickets is that he to whom one
is given come in time for the debate and bring, if possible, a fair
partner. Further than this (and
the partner need be fair only in
her escort's eyes) the debate and
dance will be free.
B. S. Cannon, Macht and Reed
will represent the Seniors in the
debate; Keene, Marbury and
Watkins will carry the 1922 colors.
For the first time in years there
promises to be a large and interesting (if not interested) audience.

SENIORS IN FAVOR OF INCREASED ATHLETIC FEE

ORDERS RECEIVED FOR

At a meeting held on March 8
the Senior Class placed itself on
record as in favor of an increase
in the annual athletic fee of $5,
making the amount $15 instead of
$10, as it now stands. The class
wished it known that, though its
members would be unaffected by
any change, it would lend its suppost to the backers of the movement. A similar motion will be
presented to the other classes,
which will be able to consider it
with the knowledge that the older
men are in favor of it.
Coach Van Orman explained
that with the present fee it will be
impossible for the Athletic Association to maintain all of the nine
sports now on the list at Hopkins
and to give each enough money to
equip it suitably. The $15 allowance will permit a larger allowance for the swimming and tennis
teams and will aid them by a
larger allotment to make guarantees sufficiently attractive to draw
the larger colleges to Homewood.
Following the discussion and
balloting upon the athletic allowance, F. L. Hubbard, Senior Treasurer, requested a promi)t payment
of class dues in order to allow the
Hullabaloo to meet its current
bills, and R. S. Heiner, editor of
the year' book, reminded that all
Senior snapshots and write-ups
must be in by the end of this week

VARSITY CLUB MAKES ANNOUNCEMENTS
$1400 Lost on Basket-Ball Season.
More Working Capital Needed.
Eleven Students Elected to
Membership.—More
•

Wanted.

The Varsity Club announces
that it has lost $1400 on the basket-ball team this season. This
loss will be met by the surplus
from the football receipts; but,
since the Club expects to lose
about $1000 apiece on both baseball and lacrosse this spring, more
working capital will be needed.
The present capital of the Club
is invested in the additional stands
and other equipment, and can not
be used for its current expenses.
It is estimated that about $4000
Will be needed for this purpose until the close of next year's football
season. The Club plans to obtain
this from the sale of additional
stock. .
The Varsity Club intends to present a printed report of its receipts and disbursements some
time before the close of the scholastic year. Such reports are regularly presented at many other
colleges, and when the non-athletic
fee goes into effect next year will
become a necessity at our own
University for non-athletic as well
as 'athletic activities.
Eleven Undergraduates have
been elected to membership in the
Club, and a drive for more student
members is being made. All "H"
men are eligible and should see
either Bill Wood or Cashell concerning their applications.

clerk, U. S. A., will be at the
military office on Wednesday
and Thursday, March 16 and
17, to distribute Victory
Medals to students of the
university who are entitled to
them. This number embraces all who served during
the war in all branches, including the S. A. T. C. Discharge papers must be presented.

BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 15, 1921
HOPKINS BOWS TO CENTRE
IN LAST GAME OF SEASON
After Leading Through First Half J. H.
U. Courtmen Weaken and Kentuckians Win By Three Points.
Mayer and Owings Star.

In one of the best played and
most exciting basketball games of
the season, Johns Hopkins gave
Centre College of Kentucky a hard
fight to maintain its reputation of
having gone through the entire
season with but one defeat. The
Black and Blue squad played a
good game at all times, and at the
end of the first half were leading,
the score being 18 to 17, and from
then on it was quite evident to
the large crowd that if Centre expected to win she must come back
stiong in the second half.
Centre scored first, Mayer shooting a foul; Bobby Owings scored
two for Hopkins and Bill Wood
made a pretty shot from the side,
Keyes followed by making a spectacular one.hand shot; Bo McMillan shot two goals in quick succession from under the basket and
then Walden shot from the center
of the floor and caged another.
Mayer, Centre's individual star,
made seven foul goals during the
first half.
Hopkins came back in the second half determined to win with
the pass work noticeably improved. Still leading, the Black
and Blue five continued to run up
the score, first to 20 and then to
22. Then Centre led the score
with a foul and Bo McMillan spot
a goal which placed Hopkins on
the short end of a 24 to 22 score.
Centre began to play for time as
Hopkins became more aggressive.
Owings made a foul and Mayer
came back with a field goal which
ended the scoring, the final being
26 to 23.

ROWLAND ELECTED PRESIDENT OF SWIMMING
ASSOCIATION
Succeeds J. H. Reilly As Head of Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association—Hopkins Second To Rutgers In 1921 Team Standing.

Davidge Rowland, captain of
the Johns Hopkins swimming
team, was elected president of the
Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association at the annual meeting on
March 5 at Rutgers College, New
Brunswick, N. J. The elections
followed the meet held on that date
to decide the individual championships of the league. Jaegel, of
Lehigh, was c.hosen as secretary,
and E. F. O'Dair, of Rutgers, was
named treasurer.
The league at present includes
Johns Hopkins, Lehigh, Swarthmore and Rutgers, although it is
highly probable that Lafayette and
Stevens will be admitted to membership in the near future. Washington and Lee and Carnegie Tech
may also become associate members of the league.
A new ruling was adopted,
which provides that a contestant
in a dual meet between nfembers
of the league may compete in not
more than three events, and in
either the back stroke or the breast
stroke.
The recent meet held in New
Brunswick was not intended to
decide the team championship,
which is determined• in the dual
meets of the league but was simthe individual
ply staged to pick'
champion in each event. All first
places were won by Rutgers men
except the breast stroke, which
was captured by Rowland, of Hopkins. The final standing in the

PRICE 10 CENTS
TREW STARS IN "ARMS AND
.THE MAN"
Draws Much Applause From Lyric
Audience—Dramatic Club's Production Great Success—Badillo and Smith Responsible for Excellent
Scenery and
Settings.

It was the general consensus of
opinion of those present at the
Lyric last Friday night that the
Dramatic Club's presentation of
"Arms and the Man" was quite the
success that it was expected to be.
Bartus Trew as Captain Bluntschi,
the hero, was distinctly the star of
the cast, his great ease and superb
acting drawing from the audience
several bursts of enthusiastic applause.
The play was filled with many
comic parts, which were noticed
throughout the three acts, in spite
of the fact that the acoustics of
the Lyric made it necessary for
the actors to speak out of their
natural conversational tones. In
all except a few places the lines
could be distinctly heard over the
entire theater, in spite of the unusual size for an amateur play.
Great excitement was shown in
all the "embraces," either because
the actors, naturally unused to
"clinching" in real life, did it awkwardly, or because the audience,
thinking of the players as themselves, realized the unlikelihood of
Brawner and Moran "coming together" elsewhere but upon the
stage. Many laughs were also produced during the first act by the
"nighties" worn by Riana and
Catherine, and by the former's
antics in getting into bed, which
seemed to appeal very strongly to
the many students present.
The presence of the Undergraduate Orchestra, which, under the
leadership of "Mike" Bowers
played between the acts of the performance, served to make the
Club's presentation for •the first
time an "All-Hopkins" affair.

rare opportunity being coached
by Miss Clementine Walter, well

BALTIMORE, MD., MAR. ]5, 1921

At the annual election of the
Board of Control of the NEWSLETTER held last week, H. Douglas
Cotton, '22, was re-elected editorin-chief; Norvell E. Miller, '23,
was elected managing editor;
Frederick W. Lipps, '22, business
manager, and Glover C. Fallon,
'23, circulatioh manager. The new
board will hold office from next
week's issue until March, 1922.
LIMITED ENROLLMENT NECESSARY

Must the undergraduate enrollment of Hopkins be limited as has
been the undergraduate enrollment
of so many other colleges? This
is a question which has been before
the undergraduates for some time
and which can be answered, we
believe, only in the affirmative.
The university has been and is
totally unprepared to handle the
almost 100 per cent. increase in
student enrollment which has
taken place in the last few years.
We are not the only educational
institution to be faced by these
conditions, but nearly all of the
other colleges have already
adopted some drastic measures to
curtail the number of entering
students.

• We must frankly face the fact
that, as President Goodnow said,
the facilities of the university
scarcely justify the present large
enrollment and are certainly inadequate for a larger number of
In justice to the

students who are already enrolled

in the future, the university must
limit 'the number of undergraduates so that it can give each the
proper attention. Restricting the
size of the entering class is the
logical way to bring this situation
about.
If the entering class is to be restricted in numbers there must be
some definite basis of selection, as
the number of applicants will
greatly exceed the number which
can be admitted.
This basis of selection should be,
we feel, not scholarship alone, but
the qualities of leadership and
character of the applicant should
also be taken into account. The
selection would be based, therefore, on scholarship, qualities of
leadership and character.
Such additional information as
would be required could be obtained by the addition to the present application blank of such
questions as the committee of admissions and advanced standing
deemed advisable and by demanding letters of reference,in addition
to this application. In any case of
doubt between two or more applicants the question could be settled'
by their appearance before the
committee of admission and advanced standing, whose decision
would be final.
We believe that sueh a method
of selection is feasible and could
easily be worked out. We have
heard of similar and even more
difficult systems having been successfully put into'operation. Some
system of restriction is necessary
and certainly this- suggestion is
worthy of careful consideration.

WISHES LESS FREQUENT EXAMS

The organization meeting of the
tennis team was held last Wednesday at 12.20 P. M.in Room 112.
The candidates, who numbered
about 20, were addressed by Captain Duffy and Manager Pickford.
The main purpose of the meeting was to obtain the names and
past records of those enrolling in
the sport. Announcement was
made that the courts will be put
into condition as soon as possible, •
after which the spring tournaments will be started. A general
entry, blank and a copy of the
tournament rules will be posted in
several days' time.
The schedule as arranged thus
far presents some very attractive
and some rather formidable
matches. It is therefore hoped
that a team of- the calibre of previous Hopkins organizations Will
be produced.

the greatest sum total of facts and
information but it would never
develop the thirst for knowledge,
and it would never develop any
powers of original thinking. How
Often do you find a boy in prep
school who turns aside from his
daily assignments to make some
independent inquiries? Individualism is stultified by routine.
There are other incidental objections to this system, such as the
number of instructors re'quirea..
In the second place we might
put into effect the system which,
I believe has been the theoretical
one at Hopkins—responsibility on
the part of the student, checked
up by semi-annual examinations.
Such a method has a fatal flaw.
An hour's' work during the week
before exams is worth three hours
earlier in the year, as far as passing is concerned/ I would not
hesitate to say that seven-eights
of the students here are chiefly *concerned with the results of their
examinations and not with the acquisition of knowledge. Hence
they cram and acquire a knowledge which does not last two weeks
after the examination. The work
which counts, work done regularly
through the year, is generally neglected, except in preparation for
quizzes. This sounds like a very
naive attack on a well planned
system, but I am presenting the
students' view, and they are generally agreed in regard to these
facts. What Senior, Phi Beta
Kappa men included, can pass a
course which he has not taken
since Freshman year?
Lastly, a college may adopt the
English system of placing absaute
responsibility on the student, by
Postponing examinations for one,
or, better, two or three years. This
places his work in a new light in
the eyes of the student. He realizes
that the best way to pass is to

learn, and he studies with that end
in view, reading all the important
literature of a subject and reviewing when necessary. We sometimes encounter a subject which
cannot be crammed, for it covers
That is the
too much ground.
secret of this-last alternative.No
man can put off all the work covered in such a long period. He
cannot afford to procrastinate or
be very irregular in his studying.
The responsibility is obvious—the
inevitability slaps him in the face.
Such a system would afford the
student the greatest possible incentive and requirements of the
university could be standardized
and adjusted at will. The English
universities are ahead of us, and
their success shows that high
school methods are not necessary
in college.

DANCE

TO FOLLOW JUNIORSENIOR DEBATE

The Junior Class has decided
to take a step that will, if successful, set a tradition that future
classes will find most beneficial
to follow. The Junior-Senior debate this year is to be followed•
for the first time in the history of
Hopkins debating by an informal
dance. The debate, the subject
of which is the American immigration question, will begin
promptly at 8 o'clock on the night
of March 19, and anyone who is
not in the C. E. Hall by that hour
will not be admitted to the dance
afterward.
The Juniors, in aranging their
debating contest this year and
remembering the woefully small
numbers attendant on former class
debates, decided that some step
must be taken to assure the debaters an audience -large enough
to be called an audience. The
dance plan was the result. It was
thought best to have a card dance,
although it will be an informal one. Decorations will not be
lacking, for those used at the
cotillion the night before will still
be in place. The Undergraduate
Orchestra will furnish the necessary jazz, and dancers needing
refreshment will find it in the
punch for which 1922 has voted
the sum of $15 from its treasury.
The committee for the debate
consists of Cotton, '22 (chairman); Pickford, '21; Wood, '22,
Cards of
and Vanneman, '23.
admission may be obtained from
members of this committee. The
only restriction upon the issuing
of tickets is that he to whom one
is given come in time for the debate and bring, if possible, a fair
partner. Further than this (and
the partner need be fair only in
her escort's eyes) the debate and
dance will be free.
B. S. Cannon, Macht and Reed
will represent the Seniors in the
debate; Keene, Marbury and
Watkins will carry the 1922 colors.
For the first time in years there
promises to be a large and interesting (if not interested) audience.

SENIORS IN FAVOR OF INCREASED ATHLETIC FEE

ORDERS RECEIVED FOR

At a meeting held on March 8
the Senior Class placed itself on
record as in favor of an increase
in the annual athletic fee of $5,
making the amount $15 instead of
$10, as it now stands. The class
wished it known that, though its
members would be unaffected by
any change, it would lend its suppost to the backers of the movement. A similar motion will be
presented to the other classes,
which will be able to consider it
with the knowledge that the older
men are in favor of it.
Coach Van Orman explained
that with the present fee it will be
impossible for the Athletic Association to maintain all of the nine
sports now on the list at Hopkins
and to give each enough money to
equip it suitably. The $15 allowance will permit a larger allowance for the swimming and tennis
teams and will aid them by a
larger allotment to make guarantees sufficiently attractive to draw
the larger colleges to Homewood.
Following the discussion and
balloting upon the athletic allowance, F. L. Hubbard, Senior Treasurer, requested a promi)t payment
